messages.content:
You are an expert software engineer specialized in bug localization. 
Your task is to identify the files most likely to contain bugs based on bug descriptions. 
You have access to several tools to help you in this task. 
From the files you have seen, you will select 10 files that you believe are most likely to contain the bug.

<bug_description>
script run with --noupdate should not ask "Do you want to update all data sources?" > python updateHostsFile.py -n
> ←[94mDo you want to update all data sources?←[0m [Y/n]

the culprit is

> response = "yes" if auto else query_yes_no("Do you want to update all data sources?")
>     if response == "yes" and update:

query_yes_no should not be asked for update=False set by `update = not args.noUpdate`
</bug_description>

The repository name is:
<repo_name>
stevenblack/hosts
</repo_name>

You have access to the following tools:

* extract_relevant() -> Retrieve the most relevant info from the bug. Returns a JSON object with explanation, relevant code snippets, error messages and file paths mentioned in the bug. *

You must use these tools to find 10 files that are most likely to contain the bug. Start by analyzing the issue description and then decide which tool to use first.
If you are done, provide your final ranked list of 10 files most likely to contain bugs in a JSON array as follows: {"ranked_files": ["file1", "file2", ...]}
Otherwise, return only the tool call as JSON. Example: {"function_call": "func_name", "args": {"arg_name": 10} }
Reply ONLY with the JSON response.

extract_relevant: {'explanation': "The script incorrectly asks 'Do you want to update all data sources?' even when --noupdate flag is used. The bug occurs because the query_yes_no function is called regardless of the update flag value, which should be False when --noupdate is specified.", 'path': '', 'filename': 'updateHostsFile.py', 'identifiers': ['query_yes_no', 'update', 'auto', 'args.noUpdate'], 'code snippet': 'response = "yes" if auto else query_yes_no("Do you want to update all data sources?")\n    if response == "yes" and update:', 'stacktrace': '', 'error_message': 'Do you want to update all data sources?'}

content:
#Unified hosts file 

This repository consolidates several reputable `hosts` files, and merges them into a single unified hosts file
with duplicates removed.

Several variants are available.  See the table below:

**Expectation**: These unified hosts file should serve all devices, regardless of OS.

* Last updated: **March 17 2016**.

### Hosts file variants

Host file recipe | Raw hosts | Unique domains
---------------- |:---------:|:-------------:
Unified hosts = **(adware + malware)** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/hosts) | 27,266
Unified hosts + **gambling** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/gambling/hosts) | 27,979
Unified hosts + **porn** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/porn/hosts) | 32,516
Unified hosts + **social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/social/hosts) | 27,374
Unified hosts + **gambling + porn** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/gambling-porn/hosts) | 33,229
Unified hosts + **gambling + social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/gambling-social/hosts) | 28,087
Unified hosts + **porn + social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/porn-social/hosts) | 32,624
Unified hosts + **gambling + porn + social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/raw/master/alternates/gambling-porn-social/hosts) | 33,337

## Sources of hosts data unified here

Updated `hosts` files from the following locations are always unified and included:

* The [Adaway hosts file](http://adaway.org/hosts.txt), updated regularly.
* MVPs.org Hosts file at [http://winhelp2002.mvps.org/hosts.htm](http://winhelp2002.mvps.org/hosts.htm), updated

readme: #Unified hosts file 

This repository consolidates several reputable `hosts` files, and merges them into a single unified hosts file
with duplicates removed.

Several variants are available.  See the table below:

**Expectation**: These unified hosts file should serve all devices, regardless of OS.

* Last updated: **March 17 2016**.

### Hosts file variants

Host file recipe | Raw hosts | Unique domains
---------------- |:---------:|:-------------:
Unified hosts = **(adware + malware)** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/hosts) | 27,266
Unified hosts + **gambling** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/gambling/hosts) | 27,979
Unified hosts + **porn** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/porn/hosts) | 32,516
Unified hosts + **social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/social/hosts) | 27,374
Unified hosts + **gambling + porn** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/gambling-porn/hosts) | 33,229
Unified hosts + **gambling + social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/gambling-social/hosts) | 28,087
Unified hosts + **porn + social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/master/alternates/porn-social/hosts) | 32,624
Unified hosts + **gambling + porn + social** | [link](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/StevenBlack/hosts/raw/master/alternates/gambling-porn-social/hosts) | 33,337

## Sources of hosts data unified here

Updated `hosts` files from the following locations are always unified and included:

* The [Adaway hosts file](http://adaway.org/hosts.txt), updated regularly.
* MVPs.org Hosts file at [http://winhelp2002.mvps.org/hosts.htm](http://winhelp2002.mvps.org/hosts.htm), updated

You are an expert software engineer specialized in bug localization. 
Your task is to review a ranked list of files most likely to contain bugs based on a bug description. 
You have access to the evidence seen during the investigation, such as file views and BM25 retrievals.
Your goal is to review and/or adjust the ranked list of files based on your confidence that each file contains the bug.

This is the bug description:
<bug_description>
script run with --noupdate should not ask "Do you want to update all data sources?" > python updateHostsFile.py -n
> ←[94mDo you want to update all data sources?←[0m [Y/n]

the culprit is

> response = "yes" if auto else query_yes_no("Do you want to update all data sources?")
>     if response == "yes" and update:

query_yes_no should not be asked for update=False set by `update = not args.noUpdate`
</bug_description>

BM25 retrieved the following files:
<bm25_retrieved>
{
  "files": [
    "updateHostsFile.py"
  ]
}
</bm25_retrieved>

You have also viewed the following files during your investigation:
<viewed_files>
["updateHostsFile.py", "updateHostsFile.py", "README.md"]
</viewed_files>


 This is the final ranked list of files you provided: ["updateHostsFile.py", "README.md", "hosts", "alternates/gambling/hosts", "alternates/porn/hosts", "alternates/social/hosts", "alternates/gambling-porn/hosts", "alternates/gambling-social/hosts", "alternates/porn-social/hosts", "alternates/gambling-porn-social/hosts"].

You are required to return 10 files most likely to contain bugs.

Provide a confidence score for each file in the list based on this rubric:
<RUBRIC>
9-10 (Near-certain): Direct file mention in bug description or stack frame, you have seen the file content and it matches the bug context.
7-8 (Strong): Clear functional ownership and multiple strong signals (identifiers + behavior + BM25 retrieval).
5-6 (Plausible): Good topical/structural match with partial identifier/behavior evidence.
3-4 (Weak): Mostly retrieval/path proximity with little concrete alignment, no evidence.
1-2 (Very unlikely): Invalid/irrelevant, or only superficial similarity, no evidence.
</RUBRIC>

Adjust the ranking based on your confidence scores.
If your confidence score is below 7 for the first 2-3 files, you should consider replacing it with a file for which you have higher confidence.

You may reply with ONE of these JSON shapes ONLY:
A) {"ranked_files": ["file1", "file2", ...], "confidence_scores": ["score1", "score2", ...]}
B) {"function_call":"view_file","args":{"file_path":string}}
Never include code blocks, file contents, or extra keys.
If you are about to paste file content, STOP and return JSON instead.
Reply ONLY with the required JSON format.
